summary: It’s not strange that Ghost and Sansa never had close scene during 2 season?
body:
It’s not strange that Ghost and Sansa never had close scene during 2 season?

Ghost is part of Jon.

He is very special creature for Jon but during 2 season Ghost never ever pets by her, Ghost never ever tried to Follow her, Never ever tried to protect her.

Show creators told that they planned season 7. Jon could to tell Ghost “protect my sister “ but they cut this scene from outline.

It’s very special that Ghost takes his attention with persons who is important for Jon.

We remembered Sam,Gily, Ygritte, Ghost protected Jeor Mormont. He was close with Maester Aemon too. But why not Sansa?

Why never ever Ghost attended Sansa ?

Guys Have you idea?

summary: “When you’re old enough, I will make you a match (...)”
title: “When you’re old enough, I will make you a match (...)”
body:
A few days ago I read a short meta on the Good Queen Alysanne/Sansa parallels, and some anti came screaming that “you Jonsas will steal everything and try and make it suit your needs”, Ned’s words used as one of the examples.

This inspired me to share this confession which may sound obvious but again–apparently there are many people refusing to just let the others ship whatever the hell they want.

Me, personally, I don’t believe that Ned was talking about Jon. I don’t believe he was talking about anyone in particular, his only agenda was to get the girls out of King’s Landing ASAP. Away from Cersei, Joffrey, the Lannisters… Jon was wearing black at that time anyway, and even if Ned had planned to make a match between them before everything happened (which I don’t believe either), he wouldn’t even think of it after Jon had joined the Night’s Watch. It was a done deal. I’m sure that it’s not what Ned had planned for Lyanna’s son, but better the Wall than Robert’s hammer. And besides, I don’t think that he’d be too thrilled about Jonsa. Lyanna’s boy or not, Jon was raised as his son, I’m like 99% percent certain that the prospect of “his son” courting his daughter would appear extremely icky to him.

(I’m all on board with the “but they weren’t close as children” argument–they were indeed not, and them being once-siblings doesn’t discourage me from shipping them–but I’m trying to focus on Ned’s perspective here.)

So yeah, I don’t believe he was talking directly about Jon. I cannot speak for all the Jonsas out there, but most of us don’t believe that either. What we do believe is that it may have been a kinda sorta foreshadowing for Sansa, and that she will in fact be matched with “a high lord who’s worthy of [her], someone brave and gentle and strong”, and that this “someone” will be Jon himself, the rightful heir to the Iron Throne.

Has it been confirmed anywhere in the books? No. Has it been explicitly contradicted? Also no. Yes, we are looking for clues supporting our ships, BIG SURPRISE! Some of them are just wishful thinking, some of them may actually be proven right at some point. As far as “wild theories” are concerned, neither Jon being “the match that was promised”, nor the Good Queen Alysanne/Sansa parallels are extremely far-fetched. 

Quoting Bridget Jones: “Let’s see, shall we?” Ship and let ship. I wish you all good fortune in the wars to come!

blog.title: Enjoy the little things!
blog.description:
Open your heart
To the love of the world
It only needs one person
Touching it with 
A word
A look
A smile
A kiss

title: Souls of the Dead
body:
Written for @jonsa-week Day 1: The Father

He loved her. He loved her more than he could bear. He loved her that much that seeing her withering away like this, shattered his heart into a thousand little pieces. “Do you want to go home?”

Or a Hades and Persephone retelling with Jon as Hades and Sansa as Persephone and no involuntarily kidnapping ;-)

He loved her. He loved her more than he could bear. He loved her more than he would admit and could admit. Every time he looked at her, his heart skipped a beat. Every time he talked to her, he just wanted to lean back and listen. Every time he was with her, he forgot the rest of the underworld, the heavy weight on his shoulders, the calling of his duties.

And she loved him too. But despite her love for him, there was a certain unhappiness in her eyes, in her voice, in the way she walked around. She wasn’t made to hide in the shadows and linger in the darkness. Just like a flower couldn’t fully bloom in the cold snow.

“Sansa?” Jon watched her full plate.

During the last half an hour she had barely eaten anything, apart from 6 small seeds from the pomegranate. Her cheeks had once been rosy and blushed, but the color was fading and only whiteness remained.

He loved her. He loved her more than he could bear. He loved her that much that seeing her withering away like this, shattered his heart into a thousand little pieces. “Do you want to go home?”

“Home?” Sansa looked up and her eyes widened. The sudden gleam that brightened them made a pleasant warmth spread through Jon’s entire body.

“To Winterfell. To your mother. To your sister. To your brothers.” He reached for her hand and he tried to warm her ice cold skin between his own palms. He was nothing without her. He had been nothing before they had met. And he would return to be nothing when she had left. But he couldn’t keep her here, locked up and sealed away from the world she loved so much.

Sansa shook her head. “Would you come with me?” She whispered. She loved him too. She loved him, but detested his world, his kingdom and his reign. How could he ever blame her? How could he blame the sun for hating the night?

“I can’t.” He bent his head, but his hands kept on holding onto hers. “My people need me. My kingdom needs me. If I’m gone, there will be nothing but chaos.”

Sansa’s lips formed a straight line.

He remembered the first time he had seen her.

She had been climbing trees with her brothers. Higher and higher and higher, as if they had tried to reach the top of the Olympus, even though they were only demi-Gods and would never be allowed to enter. When she had almost gotten there she had fallen down, all the way to the ground. Her backbone had cracked, little bones in her body had broken and for a few short seconds her heart had stopped beating.

But even in death she had been beautiful. Despite her fall, she had smiled. She had smiled because she had attempted to reach one Goddamned place and had made it to another. She had told him about the irony in that and how even demi-Gods didn’t seem to be free from the cruel games the Gods liked to play.

He had assured her he was not a cruel God. He was not playing games. And he had told her that her time hadn’t come yet, that he would send her back to live a much longer life than the one she had already had.

But she had come back. She had jumped off the highest tower of Winterfell. She had drowned herself in the ice cold water of the melting snow after a terrible long winter. She had bled herself dry using her brother’s sword.

And every time he had told her that it was not her time yet. That she had a much longer life to live and that he would sent her back to live it.

“But I love you…” She had whispered. “I want to be with you.”

“You don’t know what you ask for.” He had answered. And he had let her go again.

“The last thing I want is for you to be unhappy.” Jon whispered and the tip of his finger draw circles on her ice cold skin. “I never wanted you to be unhappy.”

Jon had rarely left the Underworld. The underworld was his home, his kingdom. But he had made one exception once. He had saddled the horses all by himself to make sure no one knew he had gone. He had cracked open the earth, moving swiftly and quickly so he could close it again before anyone could notice the unusual light coming in.

Winterfell had prepared itself for the coming Winter at that time, but all the preparations had stopped when he had entered through the wide open gate. People had stared at him, Ned and Catelyn had rushed out of the castle with fear in their eyes. But he had assured them that he was simply here to ask for their daughter’s hand in marriage.

And in that moment they had understood why their daughter had become reckless. Why Sansa had jumped off roofs and dove into ice cold water. In that moment they had understood that the God of the Underworld and the first born lady of Winterfell had fallen in love.

With tears in their eyes they had watched them leave. Jon had had his hand around her waist, holding her tightly, telling her to look over her shoulder to say goodbye to her family for as long as she could, because she would not see them again for a very long while. And Sansa had done so. But she had not cried. She had smiled. She had smiled because she could be with him and he could be with her.

“I’ll be unhappy for the rest of my life.” Sansa sighed. “If I go home, I’ll be unhappy because I won’t be with you. If I stay, I’ll be unhappy because I miss the burning sun and the holy tree blossoming.” She pulled her hand back and bent her head. “It does seem that cruel Gods did play an evil game when they let me fall on that first day I met you.”

Jon stood up from his seat and walked towards her. Nothing he could do would truly comfort her. He knew that because he had tried, night after night and day after day. But he wrapped his arms around her anyway and he held her while tears rolled down her cheeks. “You can have it both.” He sighed. “Not at the same time, but still.” Jon rocked her back and forth in his arms. “Go home during the spring- and summertime. Warm yourself in the sun, spend time with your parents and siblings, ride horses and feel the wind through your hair.” He let his head rest on hers. “And when Winter is coming you will return to me to rule by my side, to judge the souls that enter my realm, to love me and to make up for lost time.”

Sansa looked up. Even with traces of salted tears on her cheeks she still looked beautiful. “I love you, Jon Snow.” She stood up from her seat and cupped his face. Her lips brushed his, softly and gently and then fiercely and passionately. “And I will think of you every day we’re apart.”

Jon wiped her hair from her face and used his thumbs to wipe her tears away. “There won’t be a minute I won’t be thinking of you. But we have eternity. There is still plenty of time to love.“

Her backbone had cracked, little bones in her body had broken and for a few short seconds her heart had stopped beating.

But even in death she had been beautiful. Despite her fall, she had smiled. She had smiled because she had attempted to reach one Goddamned place and had made it to another. She had told him about the irony in that and how even demi-Gods didn’t seem to be free from the cruel games the Gods liked to play.

He had assured her he was not a cruel God. He was not playing games. And he had told her that her time hadn’t come yet, that he would send her back to live a much longer life than the one she had already had.

But she had come back. She had jumped off the highest tower of Winterfell. She had drowned herself in the ice cold water of the melting snow after a terrible long winter. She had bled herself dry using her brother’s sword.

And every time he had told her that it was not her time yet. That she had a much longer life to live and that he would sent her back to live it.

“But I love you…” She had whispered. “I want to be with you.”

“You don’t know what you ask for.” He had answered. And he had let her go again.

“The last thing I want is for you to be unhappy.” Jon whispered and the tip of his finger draw circles on her ice cold skin. “I never wanted you to be unhappy.”

Jon had rarely left the Underworld. The underworld was his home, his kingdom. But he had made one exception once. He had saddled the horses all by himself to make sure no one knew he had gone. He had cracked open the earth, moving swiftly and quickly so he could close it again before anyone could notice the unusual light coming in.

Winterfell had prepared itself for the coming Winter at that time, but all the preparations had stopped when he had entered through the wide open gate. People had stared at him, Ned and Catelyn had rushed out of the castle with fear in their eyes. But he had assured them that he was simply here to ask for their daughter’s hand in marriage.

And in that moment they had understood why their daughter had become reckless. Why Sansa had jumped off roofs and dove into ice cold water. In that moment they had understood that the God of the Underworld and the first born lady of Winterfell had fallen in love.

With tears in their eyes they had watched them leave. Jon had had his hand around her waist, holding her tightly, telling her to look over her shoulder to say goodbye to her family for as long as she could, because she would not see them again for a very long while. And Sansa had done so. But she had not cried. She had smiled. She had smiled because she could be with him and he could be with her.

“I’ll be unhappy for the rest of my life.” Sansa sighed. “If I go home, I’ll be unhappy because I won’t be with you. If I stay, I’ll be unhappy because I miss the burning sun and the holy tree blossoming.” She pulled her hand back and bent her head. “It does seem that cruel Gods did play an evil game when they let me fall on that first day I met you.”

Jon stood up from his seat and walked towards her. Nothing he could do would truly comfort her. He knew that because he had tried, night after night and day after day. But he wrapped his arms around her anyway and he held her while tears rolled down her cheeks. “You can have it both.” He sighed. “Not at the same time, but still.” Jon rocked her back and forth in his arms. “Go home during the spring- and summertime. Warm yourself in the sun, spend time with your parents and siblings, ride horses and feel the wind through your hair.” He let his head rest on hers. “And when Winter is coming you will return to me to rule by my side, to judge the souls that enter my realm, to love me and to make up for lost time.”

Sansa looked up. Even with traces of salted tears on her cheeks she still looked beautiful. “I love you, Jon Snow.” She stood up from her seat and cupped his face. Her lips brushed his, softly and gently and then fiercely and passionately. “And I will think of you every day we’re apart.”

Jon wiped her hair from her face and used his thumbs to wipe her tears away. “There won’t be a minute I won’t be thinking of you. But we have eternity. There is still plenty of time to love.“
trail.content:
Written for @jonsa-week Day 1: The Father

He loved her. He loved her more than he could bear. He loved her that much that seeing her withering away like this, shattered his heart into a thousand little pieces. “Do you want to go home?”

Or a Hades and Persephone retelling with Jon as Hades and Sansa as Persephone and no involuntarily kidnapping ;-)

He loved her. He loved her more than he could bear. He loved her more than he would admit and could admit. Every time he looked at her, his heart skipped a beat. Every time he talked to her, he just wanted to lean back and listen. Every time he was with her, he forgot the rest of the underworld, the heavy weight on his shoulders, the calling of his duties.

And she loved him too. But despite her love for him, there was a certain unhappiness in her eyes, in her voice, in the way she walked around. She wasn’t made to hide in the shadows and linger in the darkness. Just like a flower couldn’t fully bloom in the cold snow.

“Sansa?” Jon watched her full plate.

During the last half an hour she had barely eaten anything, apart from 6 small seeds from the pomegranate. Her cheeks had once been rosy and blushed, but the color was fading and only whiteness remained.

He loved her. He loved her more than he could bear. He loved her that much that seeing her withering away like this, shattered his heart into a thousand little pieces. “Do you want to go home?”

“Home?” Sansa looked up and her eyes widened. The sudden gleam that brightened them made a pleasant warmth spread through Jon’s entire body.

“To Winterfell. To your mother. To your sister. To your brothers.” He reached for her hand and he tried to warm her ice cold skin between his own palms. He was nothing without her. He had been nothing before they had met. And he would return to be nothing when she had left. But he couldn’t keep her here, locked up and sealed away from the world she loved so much.

Sansa shook her head. “Would you come with me?” She whispered. She loved him too. She loved him, but detested his world, his kingdom and his reign. How could he ever blame her? How could he blame the sun for hating the night?

“I can’t.” He bent his head, but his hands kept on holding onto hers. “My people need me. My kingdom needs me. If I’m gone, there will be nothing but chaos.”

Sansa’s lips formed a straight line.

He remembered the first time he had seen her.

She had been climbing trees with her brothers. But she had come back. She had jumped off the highest tower of Winterfell. She had drowned herself in the ice cold water of the melting snow after a terrible long winter. She had bled herself dry using her brother’s sword.

“But I love you…” She had whispered. “I want to be with you.”

“You don’t know what you ask for.” He had answered. And he had let her go again.

“The last thing I want is for you to be unhappy.” Jon whispered and the tip of his finger draw circles on her ice cold skin. “I never wanted you to be unhappy.”

Jon had rarely left the Underworld. The underworld was his home, his kingdom. But he had made one exception once. He had saddled the horses all by himself to make sure no one knew he had gone. He had cracked open the earth, moving swiftly and quickly so he could close it again before anyone could notice the unusual light coming in.

Winterfell had prepared itself for the coming Winter at that time, but all the preparations had stopped when he had entered through the wide open gate. People had stared at him, Ned and Catelyn had rushed out of the castle with fear in their eyes. But he had assured them that he was simply here to ask for their daughter’s hand in marriage.

And in that moment they had understood why their daughter had become reckless. Why Sansa had jumped off roofs and dove into ice cold water. In that moment they had understood that the God of the Underworld and the first born lady of Winterfell had fallen in love.

With tears in their eyes they had watched them leave. Jon had had his hand around her waist, holding her tightly, telling her to look over her shoulder to say goodbye to her family for as long as she could, because she would not see them again for a very long while. And Sansa had done so. But she had not cried. She had smiled. She had smiled because she could be with him and he could be with her.

“I’ll be unhappy for the rest of my life.” Sansa sighed. “If I go home, I’ll be unhappy because I won’t be with you. If I stay, I’ll be unhappy because I miss the burning sun and the holy tree blossoming.” She pulled her hand back and bent her head. “It does seem that cruel Gods did play an evil game when they let me fall on that first day I met you.”

Jon stood up from his seat and walked towards her. Nothing he could do would truly comfort her. He knew that because he had tried, night after night and day after day. But he wrapped his arms around her anyway and he held her while tears rolled down her cheeks. “You can have it both.” He sighed. “Not at the same time, but still.” Jon rocked her back and forth in his arms. “Go home during the spring- and summertime. Warm yourself in the sun, spend time with your parents and siblings, ride horses and feel the wind through your hair.” He let his head rest on hers. “And when Winter is coming you will return to me to rule by my side, to judge the souls that enter my realm, to love me and to make up for lost time.”

Sansa looked up. Even with traces of salted tears on her cheeks she still looked beautiful. “I love you, Jon Snow.” She stood up from her seat and cupped his face. Her lips brushed his, softly and gently and then fiercely and passionately. “And I will think of you every day we’re apart.”

Jon wiped her hair from her face and used his thumbs to wipe her tears away. “There won’t be a minute I won’t be thinking of you. But we have eternity. There is still plenty of time to love.“

summary: To go South - chapter 33 - Battles of the mind
title: To go South - chapter 33 - Battles of the mind
body:
Another chapter of my slow-burn /season 7 AU fic is up. Bran is setting up the pieces to prepare for the attack of the WW… Also on AO3.

Bran’s left hand touched Ghost, his right hand the weirwood. He nodded at his sisters. “Let my guards wake me occasionally to give me water and something to eat, but not too often. Our enemies are close, and I have work to do to fight them. My guards must protect me, when our enemies come. If they get me here, we are lost.”

Sansa looked at him unhappily. “Couldn’t you do that whatever it is you do in the castle?”

Bran just shook his head.

“I’ll stay with you,” Arya said.

Bran shook his head again. “Meera stays with me. You know, what you have to do, Arya.”

Arya bit her lip. “Nymeria is on her way, but she’s still far.”

“Make her hurry!”

Sansa gave instruction to the dozen knights that she had dispatched to guard her brother. She had ordered them to take a bag of food each and now she placed one at Bran’s feet. With her face so close, Bran could see that her eyes were red-rimmed from crying, but listening to her giving orders to the knights, instructing Podrick to give Bran water every three hours at the very least and a bite to eat as well, Bran would never have thought that she was afraid.

“You go to the castle,” he encouraged her. “They will need the Lady of Winterfell.”

He made an effort to remember what would be expected of him. He took her hand, pressed it, and moved the muscles that made him smile.

“We have a chance. I know you will manage well. Send more people to guard me, once the Walkers come.”

He rested his hand on the direwolf’s head again.

“You’ll know when we need the wolves,” he told Arya.

Bran knew that he would look as if life had left him but sitting at the weirwood and diving into the wisdom that awaited him was the only time he felt alive now. He knew that he was living other people’s lives, that he felt other people’s love and yet all that at the same time made him dizzy and hungry for more at the same time. Knowledge and wisdom were his. It was a blessing and a burden. He could try to act at the right time from what he knew, and yet he never had the feeling he knew enough. His thirst could not be quenched and yet he had to watch himself so that he would not drown. Meera eyed him, a worried look on her face.

“We’ve talked about this. I’ll manage,” he told her.

The worry did not leave her face, but he pushed that away and delved into the swirling images that came when he touched the weirwood.

It was not that difficult to get hold of Jon with Ghost by his side. His cousin’s thoughts were set on Winterfell and it was easy to contain the dragon’s thoughts by channeling the image of the dark and humid earth around the weirwood tree. But Bran knew he had many tasks ahead and the steady hammering of his heart that beat through the images was fast. In some of his tasks he probably would fail. Still he had to try.

Jon settled on the dragon, and the others were climbing on. He and Jon had worked well together, one task was done. As if in a distinct murmur Bran heard Jaime Lannister joking about Aegon the Reluctant and his banner, just when he left Rhaegal’s mind.

In a short flick he concentrated on Nymeria. His sister’s big direwolf was easy as well. Although Arya had made a face everytime Bran had told her to reach her wolf Bran could feel that their connection was stronger and was still growing stronger. He only had to nudge a little. The wolf was already bound for Winterfell in a fast pace. It was good that she had been North of the Neck already, when Bran had reached out to her weeks ago. The wolf had already sensed Arya and followed her. Nymeria would be here soon.

He sent his mind further North, carefully and stealthily so that his enemy would not sense him. He was a thin tendril of smoke, a feather on the wind, high in the air. Bran could feel the Wall, but it felt different. Not like the strong structure it had been, not like the taut bowstring it had been when he had passed the Wall. The tension was gone, the Wall was breached, Bran could see the army of the dead flooding through the wall, their strides slow but with a dogged intent set on the path to Winterfell. The wights’ masters were driving them onwards relentlessly.

Bran retreated and chided himself for checking what he had known would happen. Bran knew that he was postponing the inevitable. The other dragon. He was south of the neck, he had a strong connection to his mother, and the indifference of a huge predator to smaller beings. But Bran had to try, for several reasons.

He rooted himself deeply into the weirwood and reached out, stretching himself thin, entering the pit of fire that was Drogon’s mind. A red and gold furnace that was beautiful and dangerous, so dangerous. He stayed in the background and listened.

“I will have my revenge on Cersei. She tried to control my dragons, I’ll see her pay for that.” Daenerys insisted. Her words were muffled in the dragon’s mind. Tyrion Lannister was standing at her side, his figure small before the huge dragon. He looked very unhappy. Daenerys reached up and petted the dragon. Bran would not have understood the words, if he had not seen this scene several times already, always looking for the loophole, the breach in the wall, the opportunity to give a nudge to the scales to that they would swing another way.

“Your Grace, you saw that the dragons are not invincible. It is a great risk you want to take.”

Through the dragon’s mind Bran could feel the barely contained anger of the dragon’s mother.

“I’ll fly to the Red Keep on Drogon and set fire to it. We haven’t been using the dragons to our best advantage. We burnt some carts, harassed our enemies. It is not enough. I will have her yield.”

Daenerys did not shout, but her cheeks were red from excitement, and her chest was heaving.

“And when I have returned, and Cersei is dead, we will see about this King in the North. He’ll bend the knee then! I’m done with waiting.”

Drogon’s mind wandered to his brother then, Rhaegal, Bran could feel it. Unlike the queen, the dragon knew that Rhaegal had a connection to another human than his mother. It was a vague unsettling feeling in the dragon’s mind and quickly Bran thought of the wind under Rhaegal’s wings, the feeling of freedom. He wove this into Drogon’s mind in thin gossamer threads not stronger than a spider’s web.

Drogon stopped scratching the earth with his claw in his unrest about his brother, reassured by the images of flying. Bran distracted him from the earthy smell of the weirwood. Bran did not allow himself to sigh in relief that Drogon would not go looking for Rhaegal. When he concentrated on the humans again, the discussion had gone on.

“Your grace, please, this is too dangerous. There are still caches of wildfire under the ground in King’s Landing.”

Daenerys snorted, her face a grimace. “I’ll just ignite the Red Keep and execute Cersei.”

Tyrion’s voice was high-pitched in agitation “Your grace, many people might die.”

“Then they should not have sided with the wrong queen. It is time to take what is mine.” She turned from her Hand and beckoned the dragon to her.

“You make me almost think that you want to protect the sister that wanted you dead.”

Bran inhaled the rich sent of the black humid earth at the weirwood tree and prepared for fighting. Where is the breach, there must be a breach! He dug his heels in.

When Daenerys had mounted her dragon, he would not take wings. Bran flooded his brain with images of the earth of Winterfell.

But what had worked with Rhaegal would not work with Drogon. Bran had no connection to the rider and even if he had, the fire of her thoughts fed Drogon’s mind until the flames of her anger flared his. The dragon’s mind became a roaring furnace that was burning in white hot flames and Bran had to leave. There were still fights ahead. He had to spare some of his strength.

He had known it all along, and yet he felt tears on his cheeks, when he felt someone shake him. He opened his eyes and drank thirstily when Podrick offered him water. His throat felt parched. He would have closed his eyes again, but Podrick insisted that he ate as well.

He let Winterfell fall back again and sent his mind south again. The person he wanted to reach now was easier. Theon was no stranger to the weirwood after all. But Theon’s mind had other pitfalls.

At least he had not wasted too much time in his effort to hold Daenerys back. He slipped into Theon’s mind when he just pulled a hood over his head. He held the hand of his sister Yara who did not look like she was in good shape. Theon turned and helped his sister to pull her hood up as well.

“We have to hurry.”

Yara gritted her teeth. “I’ll manage”.

“Theon”, Bran whispered. Theon shook his head as if a fly had buzzed by. “Theon”, Bran whispered again. Theon tapped his ear, a puzzled look on his face. “Theon”, Bran tried to shout. He glimpsed Podrick who was staring at him open-mouthed. He must have shouted in Winterfell.

Theon still had not reacted other than mistrusting the sounds he heard.

“Hurry, we must hurry.” He urged Yara forward.

Bran sent a short flash of an image into Theon’s mind. He had thought long and hard on what this image could be, something that would not remind Theon of the times he was tortured and would yet remind him of Winterfell.

It was summer, a hot day. Theon held a bow in his hand and was taking aim. Robb urged him on, shouting on the top of his lung, telling him where to aim next. Both were laughing.

Theon stopped in his tracks. “Theon”, Bran whispered again.

“What is it?” Yara wanted to know.

“Robb…. Winterfell…”. Theon’s voice was as flimsy as the rustling of leaves.

Yara frowned.

“Theon, listen and watch!” He lured him in, he sent him the sense of Winterfell, the leaves rustling in the weirwood leaves, the sun glistening in the pool below the Weirwood, the smell of the earth. In another world, or maybe in some other time, Theon came closer, his eyes wary, suddenly realising that Bran was there.

“Bran, you are alive!”

Bran looked at himself and Theon from above. Fog was dancing around their feet. Theon had reached Bran. Just in the moment he recoiled when he saw that Bran’s eyes were all white, Bran snatched at his hand. “Learn! Watch! This is the future!”

Bran sent him images in a quick order. Theon and Yara, running through the streets of King’s Landing, shouting warnings, the shadow of a dragon over the Red Keep, Balerion the black dread come again, dragonfire in the keep, growing fast, the wind picking up the flames, the green snakes of wildfire.

Three times, he sent him the pictures, then he let go of his hand and his mind.

“I’m sorry, Theon, you are the only one who can help the people in King’s Landing. You are the only one I can reach.”

Bran could not say if Theon had heard it, because Pod was shaking him again. There was a chance that he would understand, a chance, but Bran would not know before Theon came North again.

Meera insisted that he drank more. Bran felt his cheeks and was surprised to find tears.

“Did you succeed?” Meera asked.

“Yes, yes, no, partly, maybe.” He shrugged. They had discussed his course of action on their way to Winterfell, again and again.

“You already look exhausted,” she said. “You must make time for a small break.”

“Later”.

He delved into the weirwood again.

—-

Rhaegal was well under control, when Bran slipped into his mind again, but the dragon would have to eat soon. They were flying in a light snowfall and the dragon would need energy. Jon had made considerable progress and they were approaching Riverrun and the Lannister armies.

“A white wolf on a red field with a green lizard in his mouth.”

Jaime Lannister was still joking about the banner, or he was at it again. Bran couldn’t tell. Judging from the way Jon pursed his lips, it was not the first ridiculous idea the Kingslayer voiced.

“I take a white wolf on an ice-white field chequered with a green dragon on a field of grass.” Jon’s voice was flat.

“Is that your final decision, your grace?”

Jon turned around and shot Jaime a nasty look.

“If you make one more suggestion about my banner I will throw you from this dragon, understood? Being in pain from being injured only gets you some leverage. You told us yourself, that it doesn’t really matter. I want you to concentrate on how you will address the armies instead.”

Jaime Lannister did not answer immediately, and when he finally talked again his voice had lost some of his flippant tone.

“I haven’t thought much about it. We fly some rounds over the camp. You drop me off. I tell them, we have a king and that we march for the rescue of Winterfell. I guess the dragon will be very persuasive.”

Jon growled.

“Think again. We want this people fighting in a desperate war. We want to persuade them to fight against an enemy they do not know. If I pressure them by threatening them with a dragon, they will just bolt.”

“That’s all good and noble. But they probably won’t just overlook that there is a dragon. And even if no one saw a living dragon, they know what a dragon can do. And it is not as if I can hide I was burnt, even if it was not your dragon.”

“Jon, I’ll show them. I can show them, at least for a little while. You just have to make them stand and listen”.

Jon shook himself as if he was not sure what he had heard. Bran, is that you?

“Trust me, Jon.”

Bran could feel his cousin hesitating, as is he did not trust his senses, but then he nodded.

“Your grace,” Brienne interjected.

“At the parley in Saltpans you showed Olyvar Frey as proof, that you left the war between the houses aside for the good of the realm. I think it would be a good idea, if you did something similar at Riverrun.”

“Would you mind leading an army, Brienne?” Jon asked.

“Me?”. Brienne was flustered.

“You and Ser Jaime. I need someone loyal to House Stark.”

Brienne was protesting, but Jon was intent on guiding the dragon. They had approached the army now and Jon let the dragon fly several times above the heads of the soldiers.

“Olyvar, maybe you could do some announcements. Wave that cloth as if you knew what is on it.“

When they had landed, Olyvar was the first to descend.

“Behold! King Aegon, sixth of his name, King of the Andals and the First Men.!”

Bran concentrated on the dragon. When Jaime and Brienne descended their smell reached the dragon’s noistrils and Bran was quick to deflect the dragon to Jon. Rhaegal had been quick to adjust. He already associated the earthy smell of the Weirwood that Bran sent into his mind with his rider. He lowered himself on the ground, making himself as small as a dragon could get, and set his golden eyes to look at Jon, an oversized dog apparently waiting on his master.

The army was abuzz, and Bran could see that several officers came closer, their stance a mixture of wariness, awe and curiosity.

Jaime Lannister raised his hand, the golden one and pointed at Jon.

“Behold! King Aegon, sixth of his name, King of the Andals and the First Men!” he shouted.

Jon stood straight, his face a mask, serious, guarded and yet not aloof. Even Bran could not have said, what his thoughts were.

Jaime Lannister raised his voice again.

“Prince Rhaegar’s son has come in the hour of our need. He has laid aside all the wars of the houses, so that we can face the threat that comes upon us unexpectedly from the North. We’ll stand together against the enemy that would destroy us all.”

“I, Jaime of House Lannister, pledge my oath to King Aegon. I have promised to fight when he protects the seven kingdoms.” He sank on his knees and drew his sword with a flourish. Bran could almost hear the collective gasp.

“Jon, tell them, and then I can show everybody how things are in the North.”

Jon waited a moment before he accepted Jaime’s sword.

He raised it above his head.

“I pledge my oath to the peace and the prosperity of all the seven kingdoms. We lay aside the petty squabbles of the Game of Thrones.”

He pointed at Olyvar. “Olyvar of House Frey and Jaime of House Lannister have seen the threat that awaits us all. We need to stand together! The White Walkers have come again, but I know the living will fight. I know you will fight!”

He gestured to the dragon and Bran acted. He slipped deep into Rhaegal’s mind and the dragon rose. He pointed his head to the air and a roaring flame ascended. The snow flakes melted in the heat and produced a myriad of glittering drops. Bran pushed with all the strength he had.

The wall of ice rose a thousand feet and more. It looked strong and unsurmountable. But like a taut bow that snapped, a section on top of the wall blew outward and it crumbled fast. When the ice dust had settled, the breach in the wall was clearly visible, and the Undead came through, their rotting corpses a terrible sight. body_abstract:
Another chapter of my slow-burn /season 7 AU fic is up. Bran is setting up the pieces to prepare for the attack of the WW… Also on AO3.

Bran’s left hand touched Ghost, his right hand the weirwood. He nodded at his sisters. “Let my guards wake me occasionally to give me water and something to eat, but not too often. Our enemies are close, and I have work to do to fight them. My guards must protect me, when our enemies come. If they get me here, we are lost.”

Sansa looked at him unhappily. “Couldn’t you do that whatever it is you do in the castle?”

Bran just shook his head.

“I’ll stay with you,” Arya said.

Bran’s left hand touched Ghost, his right hand the weirwood. He nodded at his sisters. “Let my guards wake me occasionally to give me water and something to eat, but not too often. Our enemies are close, and I have work to do to fight them. My guards must protect me, when our enemies come. If they get me here, we are lost.”

Sansa looked at him unhappily. “Couldn’t you do that whatever it is you do in the castle?”

Bran just shook his head.

“I’ll stay with you,” Arya said.

[[MORE]]

Bran shook his head again. “Meera stays with me. You know, what you have to do, Arya.”

Arya bit her lip. “Nymeria is on her way, but she’s still far.”

“Make her hurry!”

Sansa gave instruction to the dozen knights that she had dispatched to guard her brother. She had ordered them to take a bag of food each and now she placed one at Bran’s feet. With her face so close, Bran could see that her eyes were red-rimmed from crying, but listening to her giving orders to the knights, instructing Podrick to give Bran water every three hours at the very least and a bite to eat as well, Bran would never have thought that she was afraid.

“You go to the castle,” he encouraged her. “They will need the Lady of Winterfell.”

He made an effort to remember what would be expected of him. He took her hand, pressed it, and moved the muscles that made him smile.

“We have a chance. I know you will manage well. Send more people to guard me, once the Walkers come.”

He rested his hand on the direwolf’s head again.

“You’ll know when we need the wolves,” he told Arya.

Bran knew that he would look as if life had left him but sitting at the weirwood and diving into the wisdom that awaited him was the only time he felt alive now. He knew that he was living other people’s lives, that he felt other people’s love and yet all that at the same time made him dizzy and hungry for more at the same time. Knowledge and wisdom were his. It was a blessing and a burden. He could try to act at the right time from what he knew, and yet he never had the feeling he knew enough. His thirst could not be quenched and yet he had to watch himself so that he would not drown. Meera eyed him, a worried look on her face.

“We’ve talked about this. I’ll manage,” he told her.

The worry did not leave her face, but he pushed that away and delved into the swirling images that came when he touched the weirwood.

It was not that difficult to get hold of Jon with Ghost by his side. His cousin’s thoughts were set on Winterfell and it was easy to contain the dragon’s thoughts by channeling the image of the dark and humid earth around the weirwood tree. But Bran knew he had many tasks ahead and the steady hammering of his heart that beat through the images was fast. In some of his tasks he probably would fail. Still he had to try.

Jon settled on the dragon, and the others were climbing on. He and Jon had worked well together, one task was done. As if in a distinct murmur Bran heard Jaime Lannister joking about Aegon the Reluctant and his banner, just when he left Rhaegal’s mind.

In a short flick he concentrated on Nymeria. His sister’s big direwolf was easy as well. Although Arya had made a face everytime Bran had told her to reach her wolf Bran could feel that their connection was stronger and was still growing stronger. He only had to nudge a little. The wolf was already bound for Winterfell in a fast pace. It was good that she had been North of the Neck already, when Bran had reached out to her weeks ago. The wolf had already sensed Arya and followed her. Nymeria would be here soon.

He sent his mind further North, carefully and stealthily so that his enemy would not sense him. He was a thin tendril of smoke, a feather on the wind, high in the air. Bran could feel the Wall, but it felt different. Not like the strong structure it had been, not like the taut bowstring it had been when he had passed the Wall. The tension was gone, the Wall was breached, Bran could see the army of the dead flooding through the wall, their strides slow but with a dogged intent set on the path to Winterfell. The wights’ masters were driving them onwards relentlessly.

Bran retreated and chided himself for checking what he had known would happen. Bran knew that he was postponing the inevitable. The other dragon. He was south of the neck, he had a strong connection to his mother, and the indifference of a huge predator to smaller beings. But Bran had to try, for several reasons.

He rooted himself deeply into the weirwood and reached out, stretching himself thin, entering the pit of fire that was Drogon’s mind. A red and gold furnace that was beautiful and dangerous, so dangerous. He stayed in the background and listened.

“I will have my revenge on Cersei. She tried to control my dragons, I’ll see her pay for that.” Daenerys insisted. Her words were muffled in the dragon’s mind. Tyrion Lannister was standing at her side, his figure small before the huge dragon. He looked very unhappy. Daenerys reached up and petted the dragon. Bran would not have understood the words, if he had not seen this scene several times already, always looking for the loophole, the breach in the wall, the opportunity to give a nudge to the scales to that they would swing another way.

“Your Grace, you saw that the dragons are not invincible. It is a great risk you want to take.”

Through the dragon’s mind Bran could feel the barely contained anger of the dragon’s mother.

“I’ll fly to the Red Keep on Drogon and set fire to it. We haven’t been using the dragons to our best advantage. We burnt some carts, harassed our enemies. It is not enough. I will have her yield.”

Daenerys did not shout, but her cheeks were red from excitement, and her chest was heaving.

“And when I have returned, and Cersei is dead, we will see about this King in the North. He’ll bend the knee then! I’m done with waiting.”

Drogon’s mind wandered to his brother then, Rhaegal, Bran could feel it. Unlike the queen, the dragon knew that Rhaegal had a connection to another human than his mother. It was a vague unsettling feeling in the dragon’s mind and quickly Bran thought of the wind under Rhaegal’s wings, the feeling of freedom. He wove this into Drogon’s mind in thin gossamer threads not stronger than a spider’s web.

Drogon stopped scratching the earth with his claw in his unrest about his brother, reassured by the images of flying. Bran distracted him from the earthy smell of the weirwood. Bran did not allow himself to sigh in relief that Drogon would not go looking for Rhaegal. When he concentrated on the humans again, the discussion had gone on.

“Your grace, please, this is too dangerous. There are still caches of wildfire under the ground in King’s Landing.”

Daenerys snorted, her face a grimace. “I’ll just ignite the Red Keep and execute Cersei.”

Tyrion’s voice was high-pitched in agitation “Your grace, many people might die.”

“Then they should not have sided with the wrong queen. It is time to take what is mine.” She turned from her Hand and beckoned the dragon to her.

“You make me almost think that you want to protect the sister that wanted you dead.”

Bran inhaled the rich sent of the black humid earth at the weirwood tree and prepared for fighting. Where is the breach, there must be a breach! He dug his heels in.

When Daenerys had mounted her dragon, he would not take wings. Bran flooded his brain with images of the earth of Winterfell.

But what had worked with Rhaegal would not work with Drogon. Bran had no connection to the rider and even if he had, the fire of her thoughts fed Drogon’s mind until the flames of her anger flared his. The dragon’s mind became a roaring furnace that was burning in white hot flames and Bran had to leave. There were still fights ahead. He had to spare some of his strength.

He had known it all along, and yet he felt tears on his cheeks, when he felt someone shake him. He opened his eyes and drank thirstily when Podrick offered him water. His throat felt parched. He would have closed his eyes again, but Podrick insisted that he ate as well.

He let Winterfell fall back again and sent his mind south again. The person he wanted to reach now was easier. Theon was no stranger to the weirwood after all. But Theon’s mind had other pitfalls.

At least he had not wasted too much time in his effort to hold Daenerys back. He slipped into Theon’s mind when he just pulled a hood over his head. He held the hand of his sister Yara who did not look like she was in good shape. Theon turned and helped his sister to pull her hood up as well.

“We have to hurry.”

Yara gritted her teeth. “I’ll manage”.

“Theon”, Bran whispered. Theon shook his head as if a fly had buzzed by. “Theon”, Bran whispered again. Theon tapped his ear, a puzzled look on his face. “Theon”, Bran tried to shout. He glimpsed Podrick who was staring at him open-mouthed. He must have shouted in Winterfell.

Theon still had not reacted other than mistrusting the sounds he heard.

“Hurry, we must hurry.” He urged Yara forward.

Bran sent a short flash of an image into Theon’s mind. He had thought long and hard on what this image could be, something that would not remind Theon of the times he was tortured and would yet remind him of Winterfell.

It was summer, a hot day. Theon held a bow in his hand and was taking aim. Robb urged him on, shouting on the top of his lung, telling him where to aim next. Both were laughing.

Theon stopped in his tracks. “Theon”, Bran whispered again.

“What is it?” Yara wanted to know.

“Robb…. Winterfell…”. Theon’s voice was as flimsy as the rustling of leaves.

Yara frowned.

“Theon, listen and watch!” He lured him in, he sent him the sense of Winterfell, the leaves rustling in the weirwood leaves, the sun glistening in the pool below the Weirwood, the smell of the earth. In another world, or maybe in some other time, Theon came closer, his eyes wary, suddenly realising that Bran was there.

“Bran, you are alive!”

Bran looked at himself and Theon from above. Fog was dancing around their feet. Theon had reached Bran. Just in the moment he recoiled when he saw that Bran’s eyes were all white, Bran snatched at his hand. “Learn! Watch! This is the future!”

Bran sent him images in a quick order. Theon and Yara, running through the streets of King’s Landing, shouting warnings, the shadow of a dragon over the Red Keep, Balerion the black dread come again, dragonfire in the keep, growing fast, the wind picking up the flames, the green snakes of wildfire.

Three times, he sent him the pictures, then he let go of his hand and his mind.

“I’m sorry, Theon, you are the only one who can help the people in King’s Landing. You are the only one I can reach.”

Bran could not say if Theon had heard it, because Pod was shaking him again. There was a chance that he would understand, a chance, but Bran would not know before Theon came North again.

Meera insisted that he drank more. Bran felt his cheeks and was surprised to find tears.

“Did you succeed?” Meera asked.

“Yes, yes, no, partly, maybe.” He shrugged. They had discussed his course of action on their way to Winterfell, again and again.

“You already look exhausted,” she said. “You must make time for a small break.”

“Later”.

He delved into the weirwood again.

—-

Rhaegal was well under control, when Bran slipped into his mind again, but the dragon would have to eat soon. They were flying in a light snowfall and the dragon would need energy. Jon had made considerable progress and they were approaching Riverrun and the Lannister armies.

“A white wolf on a red field with a green lizard in his mouth.”

Jaime Lannister was still joking about the banner, or he was at it again. Bran couldn’t tell. Judging from the way Jon pursed his lips, it was not the first ridiculous idea the Kingslayer voiced.

“I take a white wolf on an ice-white field chequered with a green dragon on a field of grass.” Jon’s voice was flat.

“Is that your final decision, your grace?”

Jon turned around and shot Jaime a nasty look.

“If you make one more suggestion about my banner I will throw you from this dragon, understood? Being in pain from being injured only gets you some leverage. You told us yourself, that it doesn’t really matter. I want you to concentrate on how you will address the armies instead.”

Jaime Lannister did not answer immediately, and when he finally talked again his voice had lost some of his flippant tone.

“I haven’t thought much about it. We fly some rounds over the camp. You drop me off. I tell them, we have a king and that we march for the rescue of Winterfell. I guess the dragon will be very persuasive.”

Jon growled.

“Think again. We want this people fighting in a desperate war. We want to persuade them to fight against an enemy they do not know. If I pressure them by threatening them with a dragon, they will just bolt.”

“That’s all good and noble. But they probably won’t just overlook that there is a dragon. And even if no one saw a living dragon, they know what a dragon can do. And it is not as if I can hide I was burnt, even if it was not your dragon.”

“Jon, I’ll show them. I can show them, at least for a little while. You just have to make them stand and listen”.

“Bran, you are alive!”

Bran looked at himself and Theon from above. Fog was dancing around their feet. Theon had reached Bran. Just in the moment he recoiled when he saw that Bran’s eyes were all white, Bran snatched at his hand. “Learn! Watch! This is the future!”

Bran sent him images in a quick order. Theon and Yara, running through the streets of King’s Landing, shouting warnings, the shadow of a dragon over the Red Keep, Balerion the black dread come again, dragonfire in the keep, growing fast, the wind picking up the flames, the green snakes of wildfire.

Three times, he sent him the pictures, then he let go of his hand and his mind.

“I’m sorry, Theon, you are the only one who can help the people in King’s Landing. You are the only one I can reach.”

Bran could not say if Theon had heard it, because Pod was shaking him again. There was a chance that he would understand, a chance, but Bran would not know before Theon came North again.

Meera insisted that he drank more. Bran felt his cheeks and was surprised to find tears.

“Did you succeed?” Meera asked.

“Yes, yes, no, partly, maybe.” He shrugged. They had discussed his course of action on their way to Winterfell, again and again.

“You already look exhausted,” she said. “You must make time for a small break.”

“Later”.

He delved into the weirwood again.

—-

Rhaegal was well under control, when Bran slipped into his mind again, but the dragon would have to eat soon. They were flying in a light snowfall and the dragon would need energy. Jon had made considerable progress and they were approaching Riverrun and the Lannister armies.

“A white wolf on a red field with a green lizard in his mouth.”

Jaime Lannister was still joking about the banner, or he was at it again. Bran couldn’t tell. Judging from the way Jon pursed his lips, it was not the first ridiculous idea the Kingslayer voiced.

“I take a white wolf on an ice-white field chequered with a green dragon on a field of grass.” Jon’s voice was flat.

“Is that your final decision, your grace?”

Jon turned around and shot Jaime a nasty look.

“If you make one more suggestion about my banner I will throw you from this dragon, understood? Being in pain from being injured only gets you some leverage. You told us yourself, that it doesn’t really matter. I want you to concentrate on how you will address the armies instead.”

Jaime Lannister did not answer immediately, and when he finally talked again his voice had lost some of his flippant tone.

“I haven’t thought much about it. We fly some rounds over the camp. You drop me off. I tell them, we have a king and that we march for the rescue of Winterfell. I guess the dragon will be very persuasive.”

Jon growled.

“Think again. We want this people fighting in a desperate war. We want to persuade them to fight against an enemy they do not know. If I pressure them by threatening them with a dragon, they will just bolt.”

“That’s all good and noble. But they probably won’t just overlook that there is a dragon. And even if no one saw a living dragon, they know what a dragon can do. And it is not as if I can hide I was burnt, even if it was not your dragon.”

“Jon, I’ll show them. I can show them, at least for a little while. You just have to make them stand and listen”.

Jon shook himself as if he was not sure what he had heard. Bran, is that you?

“Trust me, Jon.”

Bran could feel his cousin hesitating, as is he did not trust his senses, but then he nodded.

“Your grace,” Brienne interjected.

“At the parley in Saltpans you showed Olyvar Frey as proof, that you left the war between the houses aside for the good of the realm. I think it would be a good idea, if you did something similar at Riverrun.”

“Would you mind leading an army, Brienne?” Jon asked.

“Me?”. Brienne was flustered.

“You and Ser Jaime. I need someone loyal to House Stark.”

Brienne was protesting, but Jon was intent on guiding the dragon. They had approached the army now and Jon let the dragon fly several times above the heads of the soldiers.

“Olyvar, maybe you could do some announcements. Wave that cloth as if you knew what is on it.“

When they had landed, Olyvar was the first to descend.

“Behold! King Aegon, sixth of his name, King of the Andals and the First Men.!”

Bran concentrated on the dragon. When Jaime and Brienne descended their smell reached the dragon’s noistrils and Bran was quick to deflect the dragon to Jon. Rhaegal had been quick to adjust. He already associated the earthy smell of the Weirwood that Bran sent into his mind with his rider. He lowered himself on the ground, making himself as small as a dragon could get, and set his golden eyes to look at Jon, an oversized dog apparently waiting on his master.

The army was abuzz, and Bran could see that several officers came closer, their stance a mixture of wariness, awe and curiosity.

Jaime Lannister raised his hand, the golden one and pointed at Jon.

“Behold! King Aegon, sixth of his name, King of the Andals and the First Men!” he shouted.

Jon stood straight, his face a mask, serious, guarded and yet not aloof. Even Bran could not have said, what his thoughts were.

Jaime Lannister raised his voice again.

“Prince Rhaegar’s son has come in the hour of our need. He has laid aside all the wars of the houses, so that we can face the threat that comes upon us unexpectedly from the North. We’ll stand together against the enemy that would destroy us all.”

“I, Jaime of House Lannister, pledge my oath to King Aegon. I have promised to fight when he protects the seven kingdoms.” He sank on his knees and drew his sword with a flourish. Bran could almost hear the collective gasp.

“Jon, tell them, and then I can show everybody how things are in the North.”

Jon waited a moment before he accepted Jaime’s sword.

He raised it above his head.

“I pledge my oath to the peace and the prosperity of all the seven kingdoms. We lay aside the petty squabbles of the Game of Thrones.”

He pointed at Olyvar. “Olyvar of House Frey and Jaime of House Lannister have seen the threat that awaits us all. We need to stand together! The White Walkers have come again, but I know the living will fight. I know you will fight!”

He gestured to the dragon and Bran acted. He slipped deep into Rhaegal’s mind and the dragon rose. He pointed his head to the air and a roaring flame ascended. The snow flakes melted in the heat and produced a myriad of glittering drops. Bran pushed with all the strength he had.

The wall of ice rose a thousand feet and more. It looked strong and unsurmountable. But like a taut bow that snapped, a section on top of the wall blew outward and it crumbled fast. When the ice dust had settled, the breach in the wall was clearly visible, and the Undead came through, their rotting corpses a terrible sight. The White Walkers followed their piercing blue eyes focussing, so that it seemed as if they were looking at the army.

Bran could hear the cries of the soldiers, just before he fell unconscious.

Bran’s left hand touched Ghost, his right hand the weirwood. He nodded at his sisters. “Let my guards wake me occasionally to give me water and something to eat, but not too often. Our enemies are close, and I have work to do to fight them. My guards must protect me, when our enemies come. If they get me here, we are lost.”

Sansa looked at him unhappily. “Couldn’t you do that whatever it is you do in the castle?”

Bran just shook his head.

“I’ll stay with you,” Arya said.

Bran shook his head again. “Meera stays with me. You know, what you have to do, Arya.”

Arya bit her lip. “Nymeria is on her way, but she’s still far.”

“Make her hurry!”

Sansa gave instruction to the dozen knights that she had dispatched to guard her brother. She had ordered them to take a bag of food each and now she placed one at Bran’s feet. With her face so close, Bran could see that her eyes were red-rimmed from crying, but listening to her giving orders to the knights, instructing Podrick to give Bran water every three hours at the very least and a bite to eat as well, Bran would never have thought that she was afraid.

“You go to the castle,” he encouraged her. “They will need the Lady of Winterfell.”

He made an effort to remember what would be expected of him. He took her hand, pressed it, and moved the muscles that made him smile.

“We have a chance. I know you will manage well. Send more people to guard me, once the Walkers come.”

He rested his hand on the direwolf’s head again.

“You’ll know when we need the wolves,” he told Arya.

Bran knew that he would look as if life had left him but sitting at the weirwood and diving into the wisdom that awaited him was the only time he felt alive now. He knew that he was living other people’s lives, that he felt other people’s love and yet all that at the same time made him dizzy and hungry for more at the same time. Knowledge and wisdom were his. It was a blessing and a burden. He could try to act at the right time from what he knew, and yet he never had the feeling he knew enough. His thirst could not be quenched and yet he had to watch himself so that he would not drown. Meera eyed him, a worried look on her face.

“We’ve talked about this. I’ll manage,” he told her.

The worry did not leave her face, but he pushed that away and delved into the swirling images that came when he touched the weirwood.

It was not that difficult to get hold of Jon with Ghost by his side. His cousin’s thoughts were set on Winterfell and it was easy to contain the dragon’s thoughts by channeling the image of the dark and humid earth around the weirwood tree. But Bran knew he had many tasks ahead and the steady hammering of his heart that beat through the images was fast. In some of his tasks he probably would fail. Still he had to try.

Jon settled on the dragon, and the others were climbing on. He and Jon had worked well together, one task was done. As if in a distinct murmur Bran heard Jaime Lannister joking about Aegon the Reluctant and his banner, just when he left Rhaegal’s mind.

In a short flick he concentrated on Nymeria. His sister’s big direwolf was easy as well. Although Arya had made a face everytime Bran had told her to reach her wolf Bran could feel that their connection was stronger and was still growing stronger. He only had to nudge a little. The wolf was already bound for Winterfell in a fast pace. It was good that she had been North of the Neck already, when Bran had reached out to her weeks ago. The wolf had already sensed Arya and followed her. Nymeria would be here soon.

He sent his mind further North, carefully and stealthily so that his enemy would not sense him. He was a thin tendril of smoke, a feather on the wind, high in the air. Bran could feel the Wall, but it felt different. Not like the strong structure it had been, not like the taut bowstring it had been when he had passed the Wall. The tension was gone, the Wall was breached, Bran could see the army of the dead flooding through the wall, their strides slow but with a dogged intent set on the path to Winterfell. The wights’ masters were driving them onwards relentlessly.

Bran retreated and chided himself for checking what he had known would happen. Bran knew that he was postponing the inevitable. The other dragon. He was south of the neck, he had a strong connection to his mother, and the indifference of a huge predator to smaller beings. But Bran had to try, for several reasons.

He rooted himself deeply into the weirwood and reached out, stretching himself thin, entering the pit of fire that was Drogon’s mind. A red and gold furnace that was beautiful and dangerous, so dangerous. He stayed in the background and listened.

“I will have my revenge on Cersei. She tried to control my dragons, I’ll see her pay for that.” Daenerys insisted. Her words were muffled in the dragon’s mind. Tyrion Lannister was standing at her side, his figure small before the huge dragon. He looked very unhappy. Daenerys reached up and petted the dragon. Bran would not have understood the words, if he had not seen this scene several times already, always looking for the loophole, the breach in the wall, the opportunity to give a nudge to the scales to that they would swing another way.

“Your Grace, you saw that the dragons are not invincible. It is a great risk you want to take.”

Through the dragon’s mind Bran could feel the barely contained anger of the dragon’s mother.

“I’ll fly to the Red Keep on Drogon and set fire to it. We haven’t been using the dragons to our best advantage. We burnt some carts, harassed our enemies. It is not enough. I will have her yield.”

Daenerys did not shout, but her cheeks were red from excitement, and her chest was heaving.

Drogon’s mind wandered to his brother then, Rhaegal, Bran could feel it. Unlike the queen, the dragon knew that Rhaegal had a connection to another human than his mother. It was a vague unsettling feeling in the dragon’s mind and quickly Bran thought of the wind under Rhaegal’s wings, the feeling of freedom. He wove this into Drogon’s mind in thin gossamer threads not stronger than a spider’s web.

Drogon stopped scratching the earth with his claw in his unrest about his brother, reassured by the images of flying. Bran distracted him from the earthy smell of the weirwood. Bran did not allow himself to sigh in relief that Drogon would not go looking for Rhaegal. When he concentrated on the humans again, the discussion had gone on.

“Your grace, please, this is too dangerous. There are still caches of wildfire under the ground in King’s Landing.”

Daenerys snorted, her face a grimace. “I’ll just ignite the Red Keep and execute Cersei.”

He had known it all along, and yet he felt tears on his cheeks, when he felt someone shake him. He opened his eyes and drank thirstily when Podrick offered him water. His throat felt parched. He would have closed his eyes again, but Podrick insisted that he ate as well.

He let Winterfell fall back again and sent his mind south again. The person he wanted to reach now was easier. Theon was no stranger to the weirwood after all. But Theon’s mind had other pitfalls.

Theon still had not reacted other than mistrusting the sounds he heard.

“Hurry, we must hurry.” He urged Yara forward.

Bran sent a short flash of an image into Theon’s mind. He had thought long and hard on what this image could be, something that would not remind Theon of the times he was tortured and would yet remind him of Winterfell.

It was summer, a hot day. Theon held a bow in his hand and was taking aim. Robb urged him on, shouting on the top of his lung, telling him where to aim next. Both were laughing.

Theon stopped in his tracks. “Theon”, Bran whispered again.

“What is it?” Yara wanted to know.

“Robb…. Winterfell…”. Theon’s voice was as flimsy as the rustling of leaves.

Yara frowned.

tags: He's the perfect match for dracarys right?
summary: Jon is a groundbreaking action hero: a tough, gritty character, but also sensitive and vulnerable. Do you think it’s important...
body:
Jon is a groundbreaking action hero: a tough, gritty character, but also sensitive and vulnerable. Do you think it’s important to have role models like that?

I think so. I haven’t thought about it in those terms. Personally, I’m not interested in the stern, nothing-can-beat-me action hero. There’s got to be a fault there that the person is working against. John is a warrior, but he doesn’t like killing people. He’s doing the thing that’s the polar opposite to what he wants, which is peace, and that’s his conflict. My favourite superhero film recently is Logan because he’s growing older; his superpower is failing him. That’s what he’s working against.

Kit Harington - Shortlist 2018

Me, through a megaphone so D&D can hear: Don't you dare...
body:
Sansa to Arya, about Jon: When he sees you his heart will probably stop.

Me, through a megaphone so D&D can hear: Don’t you dare make Jon die just as he reunites with Arya. Please.

blog.name: reddragon1995
blog.title: Jonerys Snowstorm Of House Stargaryen
blog.description: HE LOVED HER AND SHE LOVED HIM

tags: my baby dragon is a man now
summary:
THIS SCENE.
Maester Aemon. The OG, now and always. He’s mischievous. He’s a wiseass. He’s adorable. HE BELIEVES IN THIS...
body:
THIS SCENE.

Maester Aemon. The OG, now and always. He’s mischievous. He’s a wiseass. He’s adorable. HE BELIEVES IN THIS BOY.

Whether he KNEW or not (he totally fucking knew), he had so much of a role in shaping Jon.

I miss him so much.

And look at Jon’s face, a minute ago he’s like STFU Sam, but he’s thirsty for this. He just needs someone to show they believe in him (he did get that from the LC, but he was still a steward). Also, he is relieved that he doesn’t have to live under Thorne’s command. But mostly it’s like, “This oldass motherfucking dragon who could have been king of the whole damn thing thinks I will be the best leader. That’s awesome!”


Aemon’s sitting back like a proud granddad. Jon’s proud and humbled. Somewhere above, Ned Stark and Prince Baegar are beaming with pride because if no one is gonna tell the boy he’s actually the rightful king, at least he can be the biggest shield guarding the realms of men.


Here’s to you, Maester Aemon, and you, King Crow!

Anyone who is okay with the way that D treated Jon is a Jon Snow fan in name only. She was a petulant and vainglorious megalomaniac who treated him with utter disdain and disrespect.


wow, dany never insulted jon or did any of that shit you CLAIM she did. dany didnt compare jon to joffrey or call jon stupid. OR LIE TO HIM. know who did? SANSA. know who else calls jon stupid and tears him down in order to build up a female? JONSA STANS. before and after BOTB every fucking one of you attacked jon’s character and called him stupid and said that sansa should be queen because she’s better at “ruling” than jon and knows “better” than him. 

there is no such fucking thing as a jon snow fan that ships jonsa.
